member.name: IMediaPosition.CanSeekBackward

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer and . MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer and IMFMediaEngine instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The CanSeekBackward method determines whether the filter graph can seek backward in the stream.

member.param: Pointer to a variable that receives the value OATRUE if the graph can seek backward, or OAFALSE otherwise.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include the following.

member.param: Pointer to a variable that receives the value OATRUE if the graph can seek forward, or OAFALSE otherwise.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include the following.

The get_CurrentPosition method retrieves the current position, relative to the total duration of the stream.

member.param: Pointer to a variable that receives the current position, in seconds.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value. Possible values include the following.

The IMediaPosition interface contains methods for seeking to a position within a stream.
summary.div: Note Applications should use instead of IMediaPosition.
summary.para: This interface is exposed by the Filter Graph Manager as well as by individual filters. Applications should obtain an IMediaPosition interface pointer from the Filter Graph Manager, not from a filter. The Filter Graph Manager distributes method calls to all of the renderer filters. The renderer filters propagate the calls upstream to the source filters. This sequence of events ensures that all streams remain synchronized.

If one of the distributed calls returns an error, the Filter Graph Manager returns the first error value it received. Some of the distributed calls may have succeeded in this case. However, the filter graph does not return E_NOTIMPL unless all the distributed calls return E_NOTIMPL. If at least one filter in the graph implements the method, the Filter Graph Manager does not return E_NOTIMPL.
